Windsor Foods has developed an Emergency Action and Response Plan (EARP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

III.Facility Identification
The Windsor Foods facility is located at 301 West Third Street in Toluca, Illinois.  Windsor Foods, Benardi brands is a producer of frozen italian foods.  The facility is currently undergoing a change to the east refrigeration system, which will result in an overall decrease in the total amount of ammonia on-site.

The NAICS code for the facility is 311822.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to preserve products for processing and distribution.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There are two (2) refrigeration systems onsite that are used for refrigerating coolers and freezers at the facility. 

The amount of ammonia in the west refrigeration system is approximately 6,500 pounds.  The west refrigeration system is used for cooling in spiral freezers and compressor oil cooling.  The west refrigeration system consists of two (2) high stage compressors, one (1) low stage compressor, two (2) evaporative condensers, two (2) spiral freezers, one (1) low temperature recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) intermediate intercooler, one (1) high pressure receiver, and one (1) auto purger.

The amount of ammonia in the new east refrigeration system has been calculated at approximately 13,500 pounds.  The new east refrigeration system will be used for cooling in spiral freezers, dock freezers, process freezers and coolers, storage freezers and coolers, and compressor oil cooling.  The new east refrigeration system consists of six (6) high stage compressors, four (4) low stage compressors, four (4) evaporative condensers, three (3) storage freezer evapor

ators, four (4) loading dock evaporators, two (2) cooler evaporators, one (1) cheese shredding room evaporator, one (1) filling mix room evaporator, four (4) packing line evaporators, four (4) production line evaporators, two (2) sauce kitchen evaporators, one (1) King make-up air unit, four (4) spiral freezers, two (2) thermutators, one (1) glycol chiller, two (2) water chillers, one (1) low temperature recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) high temperature recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) high pressure receiver, and one (1) auto purger.

The total amount of ammonia present on-site, including both the new east and the existing west system, has been calculated at approximately 20,000 pounds.

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.Hazard Assessment ¿ Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 

V.Hazard Assessment ¿ Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 

VI.General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur by October 30, 2010, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
·Emp

loyee Participation ¿ Windsor Foods has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses, standard operating proceures, and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
·Process Safety Information ¿ Windsor Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of July 2009.
·Process Hazard Analysis ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Windsor Foods conducted a thorough PHA study for the east and west refrigeration systems during July 2009.
·Operating Procedures ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Windsor Foods developed updated operating procedures for the east and west refrigeration systems during July 2009.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.
·Training ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards o

f the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
·Management of Change ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
·Pre-Startup Review ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
·Mechanical Integrity ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Windsor Foods formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during July 2009.
·Contractor Qualifications ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers¿ safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Windsor Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
·Incident Investigation ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
·Compliance Audit ¿ Windsor Foods

has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Windsor Foods PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The next compliance audit will be conducted by October 30, 2010.  
·Hot Work Permits ¿ Windsor Foods has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Windsor Foods reviewed their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration systems during October 2007.

VII.Five-Year Accident History
The Windsor Foods facility has not experienced any accidental anhydrous ammonia releases, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.Emergency Response Program
Windsor Foods has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Annually, Windsor Foods conducts training for facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and interacts (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Toluca Fire Protection District. 

Windsor Foods has coordinated their ERP with the Toluca Fire Protection District.  This coordination effort has included providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Toluca Fire Protection District personnel to discuss the facility¿s operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Toluca Fire Protection District personnel.

Windsor Foods has determined that the Toluca Fire Protection District will be utilized for response to all accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. 

The facility has strategically placed windsocks on the corners of the facility buildings for use in determining wind direction in the event

of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Windsor Foods operations. Windsor Foods is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Windsor Foods  

XI.Management Program
Windsor Foods has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Frank Stoeger, Facility Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
